awd_titl_txt: Mentoring Students to Success in STEM Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
The "Mentoring Students to Success in STEM Fields" project at Cornell College will increase access to a rigorous education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields for students with the intellectual ability to have successful careers in and make contributions to STEM fields, but who would otherwise not be able to access such an education because of financial constraints. The program will provide scholarships of up to $10,000 per year for 18 students whose full financial need for attendance at Cornell College has not been met.  Scholarship recipients will participate in special programming, which includes living on a Science, Technology, and Mathematics Interest Living and Learning Community residence hall floor in their freshman year, career and graduate school preparation and planning during their sophomore and junior years, and travel to local and national scientific meetings. Faculty mentors will work with the STEM Scholars throughout their time at Cornell, to help the Scholars navigate challenges and take advantage of opportunities.

This project will assess the effectiveness of curriculum-based living-learning communities at small liberal arts colleges in improving retention, graduation, and career success in STEM fields.  Specifically, this project will investigate the efficacy of nine model practices for retaining students from underrepresented populations in STEM fields and whether or not these practices also improve retention for all low income students.  The impact of the activities and programming on retention and graduation in STEM fields will be evaluated during the project and at its culmination, providing direction for improving the program while it is in operation as well as providing a final picture of the program's success. In addition, STEM faculty members will explore research-based teaching methods, and the biology department will evaluate Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) in its introductory courses, increasing the diversity of CURE models and contributing to the understanding of the impact of CURE courses on students' development as scientists.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Cornell College, in Mount Vernon, Iowa, established the STEM Scholar program when it received the NSF award (“Mentoring Students to Success in STEM Fields” NSF No. DUE-1564787) in August 2016. Over the full period of the grant, Cornell’s STEM Scholar Program supported 14 students who began as first-year students at Cornell in Fall 2017 and 9 students who began as transfer students in Fall 2017, 2018, or 2019.  These STEM Scholar students were academically talented and also had significant financial need, and they were awarded scholarships. In addition to financial support, the STEM Scholar program integrated scholarship-specific programming into all-college academic, advising, and developmental offerings.

 Intellectual Merit:

By regularly surveying the STEM Scholar students, we were able to determine the impact of the scholarship-specific programming on the STEM Scholars as they progressed through their college degree.

 In their first year, STEM Scholars were placed on a Science and Technology Interest residence hall floor with other students who expressed interest in a STEM major. The themed residence hall floor served as a focal point for social interactions among the STEM Scholars and with the other residence hall members. Surveys of the STEM Scholars found that the residence floor gave the students a strong sense of community.

 During their time at Cornell, all STEM Scholars met regularly with an assigned faculty mentor, Surveys of the STEM Scholar students found that faculty mentors had an increasingly positive effect on the students year after year, helping them deepen their understanding of career goals and steps to take to achieve those goals.  Faculty mentor meetings also increased the students’ confidence in reaching out to other faculty members, especially for help with course work. STEM Scholars also participated in monthly STEM Scholar activities with the STEM Scholar Program Manager, and met one-on-one with the Program Manager with an increased frequency as the years went on. The STEM Scholar activities were the primary way that the project continued to support the cohort connections. Of particular note was one session on Job Crafting in which the students examined what careers would bring them satisfaction. On surveys, students expressed appreciation for the STEM Scholar Program Manager due to her attention to them as whole people and her advice on issues from choosing a major to planning for future success.

 All of the STEM Scholar students were offered the opportunity to work in an on-campus work study position in a job related to their field of study beginning in the 2019-20 school year. The STEM Scholar program also supported student travel for scientific studies, presentations, and internships. Four STEM Scholars were funded to make off-campus research trips in geology and biology. Three STEM Scholars were scheduled to present results of their summer 2019 research at the American Chemical Society national meeting in the spring of 2020, but the event was cancelled due to COVID-19.  The continued mentoring of students by faculty advisors and by the STEM Scholar Program Manager on the topic of career opportunities led to offers of summer internships or research in STEM fields for many of the STEM Scholars. In the summer of 2019, 8 of the STEM Scholars had summer research or internship positions in a STEM field. In the summer of 2020, some summer experiences were cancelled due to the pandemic, but 8 STEM Scholars were still able to participate in research or internships in STEM field, although some worked remotely. In a senior exit survey, STEM Scholar students described the skills and attributes related to becoming a scientist or engineer that they gained at Cornell. 

 Broader Impacts:

The STEM Scholar program had a significant impact on the STEM Scholar students. This project provided scholarships and other support which helped 17 low-income, academically talented students graduate from college with a STEM degree.  These students got degrees in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (BMB), Chemistry, Computer Science, Engineering, Environmental Sciences, Geology, Mathematics, and Physics.  This degree will have a significant impact on their lives and the lives of those around them When asked in their senior exit survey about the importance of the STEM Scholar program and the scholarship specifically, the STEM Scholars all expressed both how important the scholarship money was for being able to attend college and how important the STEM Scholar programming was for their ability to graduate from college.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Kara M Beauchamp
